heading: cancer drug results falsified
subheading: the husband and wife that falsified data from clinical trials of a new cancer drug are sent to the slammer.
author: wired staff
text: birmingham, alabama -- a husband and wife involved in testing a cancer drug have been sentenced to prison for falsifying results that helped the drug win federal approval. harry w. snyder was sentenced thursday in federal court to three years in prison and his wife, renee peugeot, to two-and-a-half years for conspiracy, mail fraud and making false statements to the food and drug administration. they were also ordered to make restitution of $26,000 to the fda.a jury in march found that the couple falsified data from clinical trials conducted between 1994 and 1995 on bcx-34, an experimental drug to treat psoriasis and skin cancer. prosecutors said the two planned to cash in when the company's stock prices rose on news of the drug's effectiveness.snyder, a former biocryst pharmaceuticals inc. vice president, oversaw clinical development. peugeot was a nurse who helped run the drug trials. biocryst reported the irregularities to the fda in 1995 and admitted that earlier test results were misleading.at the time the snyders were indicted, biocryst said authorities made assurances that neither the company nor any other employee would be targeted in the investigation. the judge allowed the pair, now texas residents, to remain out on bond pending appeal.
